subject: RE: [junit] Running tests in separate VM
msgSnippet: If you are using Ant, you can use the exec command with the fork attribute set.  If you aren t running Ant, just write an object that will start a new process
messageBody:
If you are using Ant, you can use the exec command with the fork attribute
set. If you aren't running Ant, just write an object that will start a new
process for you on the command line to run each test in its own JVM. I
don't know of anything in JUnit that you can use. Of course, in either
case, your code will have to be modified from that which is below.

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: route_m69@... [mailto:route_m69@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, July 31, 2001 3:41 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Running tests in separate VM
>
>
> Hi,
>
> I have 7 test, and i want to run each of them in a
> separate VM. Is
> there a way?
>
> Thanks
>
> Here is my test suite ->
>
> package common.clock.test;
>
> import junit.framework.*;
>
> public class Test_ClockSuite {
> public static void main (String[] args) {
> junit.textui.TestRunner.run (suite());
>
> }
> public static Test suite ( ) {
> TestSuite suite= new TestSuite();
> suite.addTest(new Test_StandardClock_1("test"));
> suite.addTest(new Test_StandardClock_2("test_2"));
> suite.addTest(new Test_StandardClock_3("test3"));
>
> suite.addTest(new Test_FixedClock_1("test_1"));
> suite.addTest(new Test_FixedClock_2("test_2"));
>
> suite.addTest(new Test_OffsetClock_1("test_1"));
> suite.addTest(new Test_OffsetClock_2("test_2"));
>
> return suite;
> }
>
> }
